title: Aberdour to Burntisland Coastal Path Walking Route

nearby.description: Dalgety Bay to Aberdour Coastal Path
Lower Largo to Shell Bay and Elie Coastal Walk

images.title: Simon Johnston / Aberdour Castle
images.caption: Aberdour Castle. The 13th century fortified residence of Aberdour was extended in the 15th, 16th and 17th centuries. It boasts a walled garden and terraces with a beehive-shaped doocot.

images.title: Richard Webb / Hawkcraig Point
images.caption: Hawkcraig Point. One of two navigation beacons aiding tankers berthing at Braefoot Bay.

images.title: Simon Johnston / Silver Sands, Easter Aberdour
images.caption: Silver Sands, Easter Aberdour. Metal detectors appear regularly on this beach in search of loot lost the previous summer.

images.title: Sandy Gemmill / Fife Coastal Path
images.caption: The view of the Fife Coastal Path leading from Aberdour to Burntisland. This section is beyond Hanging Craig

images.title: Allister Combe / Edinburgh from Fife
images.caption: Edinburgh from Fife. Looking toward Edinburgh from the popular viewpoint carpark between Burntisland and Aberdour

images.title: Paul McIlroy / Burntisland docks
images.caption: Burntisland docks. A view from Burntisland across the Forth to Leith.

description: This walk takes you along a section of the Fife Coastal Path from Aberdour to Burntisland. It runs for a distance of about 3.5 miles along a fairly flat path. Along the way there's fine views of the Forth of Leith and the city of Edinburgh. Ther walk starts in Aberdour where you can pick up the waymarked footpath and follow it east past the harbour to Hawkcraig Point. You continue along the beach and Silversands Bay to Bendameer House and Carron Habrou before coming into Burntisland. To extend the walk pick up the Dalgety Bay to Aberdour Coastal Path Walk and continue to the lovely Dalgety Bay and the ancient St Bridget's Church.
